canonical_explanation.text: Aldehydes (RCHO) contain a carbonyl group bonded to at least one hydrogen atom, while ketones (RCOR') have the carbonyl group bonded to two carbon atoms. Carboxylic acids (RCOOH) contain a carboxyl group (-COOH). IUPAC nomenclature: aldehydes use suffix '-al', ketones use '-one', and carboxylic acids use '-oic acid'. Aldehydes are prepared by oxidation of primary alcohols (using PCC for selective aldehyde formation), ozonolysis of alkenes, Rosenmund reduction of acid chlorides (RCOCl + H2/Pd-BaSO4 gives RCHO), and Stephen reduction (RCN + SnCl2/HCl gives RCHO). Ketones are prepared by oxidation of secondary alcohols, Friedel-Crafts acylation of arenes, and hydration of alkynes (acid-catalysed, gives ketones by Markovnikov rule; acetylene gives acetaldehyde as exception). Physical properties: carbonyl compounds have higher boiling points than hydrocarbons but lower than alcohols of comparable mass; lower members are soluble in water due to hydrogen bonding with water. The carbonyl group undergoes nucleophilic addition reactions because the carbonyl carbon is electrophilic. Aldehydes are more reactive than ketones towards nucleophilic addition due to less steric hindrance and less electron donation by one alkyl group versus two. Key nucleophilic addition reactions include addition of HCN (gives cyanohydrins), addition of NaHSO3, addition of Grignard reagents, and addition of alcohols (gives hemiacetals/hemiketals, then acetals/ketals). Condensation reactions with ammonia derivatives (NH2-Z where Z = OH, NH2, NHC6H5, NHCONH2) give products like oximes, hydrazones, phenylhydrazones, and semicarbazones with loss of water. Aldol condensation: two molecules of aldehyde/ketone with alpha-hydrogen undergo base-catalysed condensation to give beta-hydroxy aldehyde/ketone (aldol), which can dehydrate to alpha,beta-unsaturated carbonyl compound (cross-aldol also possible). Cannizzaro reaction: aldehydes without alpha-hydrogen (like HCHO, C6H5CHO) undergo self-disproportionation in concentrated NaOH to give one molecule of alcohol and one of carboxylate salt. Oxidation reactions: aldehydes are easily oxidised to carboxylic acids by mild oxidants; Tollens' test (silver mirror with ammoniacal AgNO3) and Fehling's test (red precipitate of Cu2O with Fehling's solution) are positive for aldehydes but negative for ketones. Ketones resist mild oxidation. Reduction: NaBH4 or LiAlH4 reduce both aldehydes and ketones to alcohols; Clemmensen reduction (Zn-Hg/conc. HCl) and Wolff-Kishner reduction (NH2NH2/KOH) convert C=O to CH2. Carboxylic acids are stronger acids than alcohols and phenols because the carboxylate ion is stabilised by two equivalent resonance structures. Acidity is increased by electron-withdrawing groups and decreased by electron-donating groups. Key reactions of carboxylic acids include formation of acid derivatives (acid chlorides, esters, amides, anhydrides), decarboxylation (heating sodium salt with NaOH/CaO), reduction by LiAlH4 to primary alcohols, and Hell-Volhard-Zelinsky reaction (alpha-halogenation using Cl2 or Br2 in presence of red P).
rules: Aldehydes are more reactive than ketones towards nucleophilic addition due to less steric hindrance and weaker electron-donating effect of one alkyl group versus two.
Tollens' test (ammoniacal AgNO3) gives a silver mirror with aldehydes but not ketones; Fehling's test gives a red Cu2O precipitate with aliphatic aldehydes.
Aldol condensation requires at least one alpha-hydrogen on the aldehyde or ketone; the product is a beta-hydroxy carbonyl compound.
Cannizzaro reaction occurs with aldehydes that have no alpha-hydrogen (e.g., HCHO, C6H5CHO) in strong base; one molecule is oxidised to acid salt, one is reduced to alcohol.
Carboxylic acids are more acidic than phenols because the carboxylate ion has two equivalent resonance structures that delocalise the negative charge equally.
Electron-withdrawing groups (e.g., -Cl, -NO2) increase the acidity of carboxylic acids; electron-donating groups (e.g., -CH3) decrease it.
Rosenmund reduction (RCOCl + H2/Pd-BaSO4) selectively reduces acid chlorides to aldehydes; the poisoned catalyst prevents over-reduction.
Clemmensen reduction (Zn-Hg/HCl) reduces C=O to CH2; Wolff-Kishner reduction (NH2NH2/KOH/high temperature) does the same under basic conditions.
HVZ (Hell-Volhard-Zelinsky) reaction halogenates the alpha-carbon of carboxylic acids using Cl2 or Br2 with red phosphorus.
Formic acid (HCHO) is the only carboxylic acid that also gives a positive Tollens' test because it contains an aldehyde-like H-C=O group.

questions.question_text: The IUPAC name of CH3COCH3 is:
questions.explanation_correct: CH3COCH3 is a ketone with a three-carbon chain and the carbonyl on C-2. The IUPAC name is propanone (common name: acetone).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Propanal is CH3CH2CHO (an aldehyde). Propanoic acid is CH3CH2COOH. Acetaldehyde is the common name for ethanal (CH3CHO).

questions.question_text: Which of the following methods is used for selective preparation of aldehydes from acid chlorides?
questions.explanation_correct: Rosenmund reduction involves the catalytic hydrogenation of acid chlorides (RCOCl) using H2 gas with Pd on BaSO4 (poisoned catalyst) to selectively yield aldehydes (RCHO).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Wolff-Kishner and Clemmensen reductions convert carbonyl groups to methylene groups (C=O to CH2). Birch reduction reduces aromatic rings, not acid chlorides.

questions.question_text: Ketones can be prepared from arenes by:
questions.explanation_correct: Friedel-Crafts acylation reacts an arene (e.g., benzene) with an acid chloride (RCOCl) in the presence of AlCl3 catalyst to produce an aryl ketone (ArCOR).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Kolbe's reaction produces salicylic acid from sodium phenoxide and CO2. Cannizzaro reaction is a disproportionation of aldehydes. Reimer-Tiemann gives salicylaldehyde from phenol.

questions.question_text: Carbonyl compounds have higher boiling points than alkanes of similar molecular mass because:

options.text: They can form hydrogen bonds among themselves
They have strong dipole-dipole interactions due to the polar C=O group

questions.explanation_correct: The C=O group is highly polar due to the electronegativity difference between carbon and oxygen. This creates strong dipole-dipole interactions between molecules, raising the boiling point above that of non-polar alkanes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Aldehydes and ketones cannot form hydrogen bonds with each other (no O-H or N-H bond), though they can accept H-bonds from water. They are covalent, not ionic.

questions.question_text: The acid-catalysed hydration of propyne gives:
questions.explanation_correct: Hydration of alkynes follows Markovnikov's rule. Propyne (CH3-C triple bond CH) adds water to give an enol that tautomerises to propanone (CH3COCH3). Note: only acetylene gives an aldehyde (acetaldehyde).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Propanal would require anti-Markovnikov hydration. Propan-1-ol and propan-2-ol are alcohols from alkene hydration, not from alkyne hydration which gives carbonyl compounds.

questions.question_text: Ozonolysis of 2-butene followed by reductive workup gives:

options.text: One molecule of acetaldehyde and one molecule of formaldehyde
One molecule of acetone and one molecule of formaldehyde

questions.explanation_correct: 2-Butene (CH3CH=CHCH3) on ozonolysis produces two molecules of acetaldehyde (CH3CHO) because the double bond is symmetrically placed between two CH3CH= groups.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Formaldehyde would only form from a terminal =CH2 group. Acetone requires a C=C adjacent to a branching point. 2-Butene is symmetric and gives identical products.

questions.question_text: Stephen reduction converts nitriles to aldehydes using:
questions.explanation_correct: In Stephen reduction, a nitrile (RCN) is reduced with SnCl2 in the presence of HCl to form an imine salt (aldimine hydrochloride), which on hydrolysis gives the corresponding aldehyde (RCHO).
questions.explanation_incorrect: H2/Pd-BaSO4 is used in Rosenmund reduction (acid chloride to aldehyde). LiAlH4 would reduce a nitrile all the way to a primary amine. NaBH4 is too mild to reduce nitriles.

questions.question_text: Which of the following aldehydes CANNOT be prepared by Rosenmund reduction?
questions.explanation_correct: Rosenmund reduction requires an acid chloride (RCOCl). Formaldehyde (HCHO) would need formyl chloride (HCOCl) as starting material, which is extremely unstable and decomposes readily, making this preparation impractical.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Benzaldehyde (from C6H5COCl), acetaldehyde (from CH3COCl), and propanal (from CH3CH2COCl) can all be prepared by Rosenmund reduction from their corresponding stable acid chlorides.

questions.question_text: Aldehydes are more reactive than ketones towards nucleophilic addition because:

options.text: Aldehydes have a higher molecular mass
The carbonyl carbon in aldehydes has less steric hindrance and less electron donation from alkyl groups
Ketones have a more polar carbonyl group

questions.explanation_correct: In aldehydes, the carbonyl carbon has one H and one R group, offering less steric hindrance. Also, one alkyl group donates less electron density to the carbonyl carbon compared to two in ketones, making the aldehyde carbonyl more electrophilic.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Molecular mass is not the determining factor. Acidity is relevant for carboxylic acids, not for nucleophilic addition. Ketones are less reactive despite having a polar C=O.

questions.question_text: When acetaldehyde reacts with HCN, the product is:
questions.explanation_correct: HCN adds across the C=O group of acetaldehyde to form acetaldehyde cyanohydrin: CH3CH(OH)CN (2-hydroxypropanenitrile). This is a nucleophilic addition where CN- attacks the electrophilic carbonyl carbon.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Acetonitrile (CH3CN) is a different compound. Lactic acid can be obtained by hydrolysis of the cyanohydrin but is not the direct product. Acetic acid requires oxidation, not HCN addition.

questions.question_text: The reaction of an aldehyde with an alcohol in the presence of dry HCl gives:
questions.explanation_correct: An aldehyde reacts with one molecule of alcohol to form a hemiacetal (with both -OH and -OR groups on the same carbon), which reacts with a second molecule of alcohol in the presence of acid to form an acetal (two -OR groups).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ester formation requires a carboxylic acid and an alcohol, not an aldehyde. The product is not a simple carboxylic acid or ether.

questions.question_text: Which of the following reacts fastest with NaHSO3?
questions.explanation_correct: Acetaldehyde (CH3CHO) is the most reactive aldehyde among the given options towards NaHSO3 due to least steric hindrance at the carbonyl carbon and only one electron-donating group.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Acetone reacts with NaHSO3 but more slowly than acetaldehyde. Benzophenone and diethyl ketone are too sterically hindered and do not readily form bisulphite addition products.

questions.question_text: When benzaldehyde reacts with hydroxylamine (NH2OH), the product is:
questions.explanation_correct: Benzaldehyde reacts with hydroxylamine (NH2OH) in a condensation reaction to form benzaldoxime (C6H5CH=NOH) with the elimination of water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Phenylhydrazone is formed with phenylhydrazine (C6H5NHNH2). Semicarbazone is formed with semicarbazide (NH2CONHNH2). Benzamide is an amide, not formed from this reaction.

questions.question_text: In the nucleophilic addition of HCN to a carbonyl compound, the actual nucleophile is:
questions.explanation_correct: HCN is a weak acid. The reaction is catalysed by base which generates CN- ions. The CN- ion is a strong nucleophile that attacks the electrophilic carbonyl carbon. The H+ is picked up by the resulting alkoxide.
questions.explanation_incorrect: HCN itself is a poor nucleophile. The H+ is an electrophile, not a nucleophile. While C of CN- attacks, it is the cyanide ion (CN-) that is the nucleophile, not HCN molecule.

questions.question_text: Arrange the following in decreasing order of reactivity towards nucleophilic addition: (I) HCHO, (II) CH3CHO, (III) CH3COCH3, (IV) C6H5COCH3
questions.explanation_correct: Reactivity decreases with increasing steric hindrance and electron donation. HCHO (no alkyl group) > CH3CHO (one alkyl) > CH3COCH3 (two alkyl groups) > C6H5COCH3 (phenyl group provides resonance stabilisation reducing electrophilicity).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Formaldehyde is the most reactive carbonyl compound due to zero steric hindrance and no electron-donating groups. Aromatic ketones are less reactive due to resonance with the ring.

questions.question_text: When acetaldehyde reacts with 2,4-dinitrophenylhydrazine (2,4-DNP), the product is:
questions.explanation_correct: 2,4-DNP reagent reacts with both aldehydes and ketones to give a yellow, orange, or red coloured precipitate of the corresponding 2,4-dinitrophenylhydrazone. This test confirms the presence of a carbonyl group.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Silver mirror is from Tollens' test. Red Cu2O precipitate is from Fehling's test. Oxime is formed with hydroxylamine, not 2,4-DNP.

questions.question_text: Tollens' test involves the reaction of an aldehyde with:

options.text: Fehling's solution (CuSO4 + sodium potassium tartrate + NaOH)

questions.explanation_correct: Tollens' reagent is ammoniacal silver nitrate [Ag(NH3)2]+. Aldehydes reduce Ag+ to metallic silver, which deposits as a shiny mirror on the walls of the test tube (silver mirror test).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fehling's solution is a separate test (gives red Cu2O with aldehydes). 2,4-DNP is a general test for carbonyl groups. NaHSO3 gives bisulphite addition compounds.

questions.question_text: Fehling's test is positive for:
questions.explanation_correct: Fehling's test is positive for aliphatic aldehydes like acetaldehyde, which reduce Cu2+ to Cu2O (red precipitate). Aromatic aldehydes like benzaldehyde do not give a positive Fehling's test.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Benzaldehyde does not reduce Fehling's solution (but does give positive Tollens' test). Acetone and benzophenone are ketones and do not reduce Fehling's solution.

questions.question_text: The aldol condensation of acetaldehyde gives:
questions.explanation_correct: In aldol condensation, two molecules of acetaldehyde react in the presence of dilute NaOH to form 3-hydroxybutanal (beta-hydroxy aldehyde, called aldol because it has both an aldehyde and alcohol group).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sodium acetate and ethanol are Cannizzaro reaction products. Acetic acid is an oxidation product. Ethanol and acetaldehyde are not the products of self-condensation.

questions.question_text: Cannizzaro reaction is given by aldehydes that:
questions.explanation_correct: Cannizzaro reaction occurs with aldehydes lacking alpha-hydrogen atoms (e.g., HCHO, C6H5CHO, (CH3)3CCHO). In strong base, one molecule is oxidised to carboxylate and one is reduced to alcohol.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Aldehydes with alpha-hydrogens undergo aldol condensation instead. Ketones and carboxylic acids do not undergo Cannizzaro reaction.

questions.question_text: When benzaldehyde is treated with concentrated NaOH, the products are:
questions.explanation_correct: Benzaldehyde has no alpha-hydrogen and undergoes Cannizzaro reaction: 2C6H5CHO + NaOH gives C6H5CH2OH (benzyl alcohol) + C6H5COONa (sodium benzoate). One molecule is oxidised, one is reduced.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both molecules of benzaldehyde are transformed: one to benzyl alcohol and one to sodium benzoate. The reaction does not produce benzene or sodium benzoxide.

questions.question_text: Clemmensen reduction of acetophenone (C6H5COCH3) gives:
questions.explanation_correct: Clemmensen reduction (Zn-Hg/conc. HCl) reduces the C=O group to CH2. Acetophenone (C6H5COCH3) is reduced to ethylbenzene (C6H5CH2CH3).
questions.explanation_incorrect: 1-Phenylethanol would be formed by NaBH4/LiAlH4 reduction. Styrene has a C=C bond. Benzyl alcohol is C6H5CH2OH, a different compound.

questions.question_text: Which of the following gives a positive iodoform test?
questions.explanation_correct: Acetaldehyde (CH3CHO) has the CH3CO- group required for the iodoform test. It reacts with I2/NaOH to give CHI3 (yellow precipitate). Any compound with a CH3CO- or CH3CH(OH)- group gives a positive iodoform test.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Benzaldehyde (C6H5CHO) lacks the CH3CO group. Propanal (CH3CH2CHO) does not have CH3CO. Benzophenone (C6H5COC6H5) also lacks this group.

questions.question_text: Wolff-Kishner reduction uses which reagent system?

options.text: NH2NH2 and KOH at high temperature

questions.explanation_correct: Wolff-Kishner reduction uses hydrazine (NH2NH2) and a strong base (KOH) at high temperature in a high-boiling solvent (e.g., ethylene glycol) to reduce C=O to CH2 with evolution of N2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Zn-Hg/HCl is Clemmensen reduction (acidic conditions). H2/Pd-BaSO4 is Rosenmund reduction. NaBH4 reduces C=O to CHOH, not to CH2.

questions.question_text: An organic compound gives a silver mirror with Tollens' reagent, a red precipitate with Fehling's solution, and a yellow precipitate with I2/NaOH. The compound is:
questions.explanation_correct: Acetaldehyde gives positive Tollens' test (silver mirror), positive Fehling's test (aliphatic aldehyde), and positive iodoform test (has CH3CO- group). No other option satisfies all three.
questions.explanation_incorrect: HCHO gives positive Tollens' and Fehling's but lacks CH3CO for iodoform. Benzaldehyde gives Tollens' but not Fehling's. Acetone gives iodoform but not Tollens' or Fehling's.

questions.question_text: In the cross-Cannizzaro reaction between HCHO and C6H5CHO in NaOH, the products are:
questions.explanation_correct: In cross-Cannizzaro, HCHO (being more easily oxidised due to stronger reducing power) gets oxidised to HCOONa (sodium formate), while C6H5CHO gets reduced to C6H5CH2OH (benzyl alcohol).
questions.explanation_incorrect: HCHO preferentially acts as the reducing agent and gets oxidised to formate. Benzaldehyde gets reduced to benzyl alcohol, not oxidised to benzoate.

questions.question_text: Aldol condensation of propanone (acetone) in the presence of Ba(OH)2 gives:

options.text: No reaction, as ketones do not undergo aldol condensation

questions.explanation_correct: Acetone undergoes aldol condensation in the presence of Ba(OH)2 to give 4-hydroxy-4-methylpentan-2-one (diacetone alcohol), a beta-hydroxy ketone. Further dehydration would give mesityl oxide.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mesityl oxide is the dehydrated product, not the initial aldol product. Hexan-2,5-dione is not an aldol product. Ketones with alpha-hydrogens do undergo aldol condensation.

questions.question_text: Carboxylic acids are more acidic than phenols because:

options.text: The carboxylate ion has two equivalent resonance structures with equal charge distribution

questions.explanation_correct: The carboxylate ion (RCOO-) is stabilised by two equivalent resonance structures in which the negative charge is equally distributed over two oxygen atoms. This makes it exceptionally stable, making carboxylic acids stronger acids than phenols.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Molecular mass and number of oxygen atoms are not direct measures of acidity. Hydrogen bonding relates to physical properties, not acid strength.

questions.question_text: The Hell-Volhard-Zelinsky (HVZ) reaction involves:

options.text: Alpha-halogenation of carboxylic acids using X2/red P
Reduction of carboxylic acids to alcohols

questions.explanation_correct: The HVZ reaction introduces a halogen atom at the alpha-carbon of carboxylic acids. It uses Cl2 or Br2 in the presence of red phosphorus (which generates the acid halide in situ as the reactive intermediate).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Decarboxylation involves soda-lime heating. Reduction uses LiAlH4. Esterification uses alcohol with acid catalyst. HVZ specifically halogenates the alpha-position.

questions.question_text: Carboxylic acids react with PCl5 to form:
questions.explanation_correct: RCOOH + PCl5 gives RCOCl (acid chloride) + POCl3 + HCl. PCl5 replaces the -OH group of the carboxyl with -Cl.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Acid anhydrides are formed by dehydration of two carboxylic acid molecules. Esters need an alcohol. Amides need ammonia or an amine.

questions.question_text: Decarboxylation of sodium acetate with soda lime gives:
questions.explanation_correct: When sodium acetate (CH3COONa) is heated with soda lime (NaOH + CaO), decarboxylation occurs: CH3COONa + NaOH gives CH4 (methane) + Na2CO3. The carboxyl group is removed as CO2 (trapped by NaOH as Na2CO3).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ethane would require sodium propanoate. Ethanol and acetic anhydride are not products of decarboxylation.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the strongest acid?
questions.explanation_correct: Acidity of carboxylic acids increases with the number of electron-withdrawing groups. Three chlorine atoms in Cl3CCOOH (trichloroacetic acid) provide the maximum -I effect, stabilising the carboxylate ion the most.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Each additional Cl atom increases the -I effect and hence the acidity: Cl3CCOOH > Cl2CHCOOH > ClCH2COOH > CH3COOH.

questions.question_text: Acetic acid reacts with ammonia on strong heating to give:
questions.explanation_correct: Initially, acetic acid reacts with ammonia to form ammonium acetate. On strong heating, this salt loses water to form acetamide (CH3CONH2).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ammonium acetate is the initial salt formed at room temperature, not the final product on strong heating. Acetonitrile requires further dehydration of acetamide with P2O5. Methylamine is from Hoffmann degradation.

questions.question_text: LiAlH4 reduces carboxylic acids to:
questions.explanation_correct: LiAlH4 is a strong reducing agent that reduces the -COOH group of carboxylic acids to -CH2OH, giving primary alcohols. It does not stop at the aldehyde stage.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Aldehydes are intermediates but LiAlH4 reduces them further to alcohols. Alkanes would require complete deoxygenation. Secondary alcohols are from ketone reduction.

questions.question_text: Arrange the following in decreasing order of acid strength: (I) HCOOH, (II) CH3COOH, (III) ClCH2COOH, (IV) FCH2COOH
questions.explanation_correct: FCH2COOH is strongest due to F having the highest electronegativity (strongest -I effect), followed by ClCH2COOH. HCOOH is stronger than CH3COOH because CH3 is electron-donating. Order: FCH2COOH > ClCH2COOH > HCOOH > CH3COOH.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fluorine is more electronegative than chlorine, so FCH2COOH > ClCH2COOH. The methyl group in CH3COOH is electron-donating, making it the weakest acid.

questions.question_text: Kolbe's electrolysis of potassium acetate solution gives:
questions.explanation_correct: In Kolbe's electrolysis, the acetate ion is oxidised at the anode: 2CH3COO- gives CH3-CH3 (ethane) + 2CO2 + 2e-. Two methyl radicals couple at the anode to form ethane.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Methane is not formed in this reaction. CO2 is produced at the anode, not the cathode. Ethanol is not a product of Kolbe's electrolysis.

questions.question_text: Gattermann-Koch reaction is used to prepare:
questions.explanation_correct: Gattermann-Koch reaction involves passing CO and HCl through benzene in the presence of anhydrous AlCl3/CuCl catalyst to form benzaldehyde. It is essentially a formylation reaction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Phenol from benzene uses Dow's process or cumene process. Benzoic acid from toluene uses oxidation. Aniline from nitrobenzene uses reduction.

questions.question_text: Which ammonia derivative reacts with a carbonyl compound to form a semicarbazone?
questions.explanation_correct: Semicarbazide (NH2CONHNH2) reacts with aldehydes and ketones to form semicarbazones (>C=N-NHCONH2) with elimination of water. Semicarbazones are often used for identification of carbonyl compounds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hydroxylamine gives oximes. Hydrazine gives hydrazones. Phenylhydrazine gives phenylhydrazones. Each derivative gives a differently named product.

questions.question_text: Which of the following reduces Tollens' reagent but NOT Fehling's solution?
questions.explanation_correct: Benzaldehyde gives a positive Tollens' test (silver mirror) but a negative Fehling's test. Aromatic aldehydes generally do not reduce Fehling's solution, unlike aliphatic aldehydes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Acetaldehyde and formaldehyde are aliphatic aldehydes that reduce both Tollens' and Fehling's reagents. Glucose also reduces both reagents.

questions.question_text: Tischenko reaction is a variant of Cannizzaro reaction. When two molecules of acetaldehyde react in the presence of aluminium ethoxide, the product is:
questions.explanation_correct: In the Tischenko reaction, two molecules of aldehyde undergo disproportionation in the presence of aluminium ethoxide to form an ester. Two molecules of CH3CHO give CH3COOC2H5 (ethyl acetate).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ethanol and sodium acetate are from normal Cannizzaro. 3-hydroxybutanal (aldol) and crotonaldehyde are from aldol condensation.

questions.question_text: Etard reaction is used to oxidise toluene to:
questions.explanation_correct: Etard reaction involves the oxidation of a methyl group on toluene using chromyl chloride (CrO2Cl2) in CS2 to form a chromium complex, which on hydrolysis gives benzaldehyde.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Benzoic acid is obtained by vigorous oxidation with KMnO4. Benzyl alcohol needs milder reduction conditions. Benzophenone is a ketone from Friedel-Crafts acylation.

questions.question_text: Acetophenone reacts with Br2 in acetic acid to give:
questions.explanation_correct: Acetophenone (C6H5COCH3) reacts with Br2 in acetic acid to undergo alpha-bromination, giving 2-bromoacetophenone (C6H5COCH2Br, also called phenacyl bromide). The alpha-hydrogen is more reactive.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bromobenzene would require ring bromination of benzene. Para-bromoacetophenone would require electrophilic aromatic substitution. Alpha-monobromination is the predominant reaction.

questions.question_text: Carboxylic acids have higher boiling points than aldehydes and ketones of comparable molecular mass because:

options.text: They form dimers through hydrogen bonding

questions.explanation_correct: Carboxylic acids form dimers through strong intermolecular hydrogen bonding between the C=O and O-H groups of two molecules, effectively doubling the molecular mass and significantly raising the boiling point.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Carboxylic acids are more polar, not less, than aldehydes and ketones. They are covalent, not ionic. The dimer formation through H-bonding is the key factor.

questions.question_text: Formic acid (HCOOH) differs from other carboxylic acids because it:

options.text: Can reduce Tollens' reagent and Fehling's solution
Does not form a salt with NaOH

questions.explanation_correct: Formic acid (HCOOH) has an aldehyde-like H-C=O group in addition to the carboxyl group. Therefore, it can act as a reducing agent and gives a positive Tollens' test and Fehling's test, unlike other carboxylic acids.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Formic acid can form esters (methyl formate, ethyl formate etc.), is acidic, and forms salts with NaOH like all carboxylic acids.

questions.question_text: When acetone reacts with CH3MgBr followed by hydrolysis, the product is:
questions.explanation_correct: CH3MgBr adds to the carbonyl of acetone (CH3COCH3) to give a tertiary alkoxide, which on hydrolysis gives 2-methylpropan-2-ol ((CH3)3COH), a tertiary alcohol.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Propan-2-ol would form by simple reduction of acetone. Grignard addition adds a carbon, giving a tertiary alcohol with four carbons. Butan-2-ol and propan-1-ol have different structures.

questions.question_text: NaBH4 can reduce which of the following?

options.text: Only aldehydes and ketones, not carboxylic acids

questions.explanation_correct: NaBH4 is a mild reducing agent that selectively reduces aldehydes and ketones to alcohols. It cannot reduce carboxylic acids, esters, or amides. LiAlH4 is needed for carboxylic acid reduction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: NaBH4 does reduce aldehydes and ketones but is too mild for carboxylic acids. It is not completely unreactive with all carbonyl compounds.

questions.question_text: Which carboxylic acid undergoes decarboxylation most easily?
questions.explanation_correct: Beta-keto acids and 1,3-dicarboxylic acids (like malonic acid) decarboxylate easily on heating because they can form a stable cyclic transition state. Malonic acid (HOOC-CH2-COOH) loses CO2 readily to give acetic acid.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Simple carboxylic acids like acetic acid, benzoic acid, and formic acid require much harsher conditions (e.g., soda lime) for decarboxylation.

questions.question_text: The common name of the simplest aromatic aldehyde C6H5CHO is:
questions.explanation_correct: C6H5CHO is benzaldehyde, the simplest aromatic aldehyde. It has a phenyl group directly bonded to the aldehyde (-CHO) group and is also known as oil of bitter almonds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Acetaldehyde (CH3CHO) and formaldehyde (HCHO) are aliphatic aldehydes. Cinnamaldehyde (C6H5CH=CHCHO) is more complex with a vinyl group.

questions.question_text: The correct decreasing order of reactivity towards aldol condensation is:
questions.explanation_correct: Aldol condensation requires alpha-hydrogen. HCHO lacks alpha-H (no alpha-carbon) and C6H5CHO also lacks alpha-H. CH3CHO (with 3 alpha-H) is more reactive than CH3COCH3 (with 6 alpha-H but lower electrophilicity). HCHO and C6H5CHO cannot undergo self-aldol condensation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: HCHO and C6H5CHO lack alpha-hydrogens and cannot undergo aldol condensation on their own (they undergo Cannizzaro instead).

questions.question_text: Esterification of benzoic acid with methanol in the presence of H2SO4 gives:
questions.explanation_correct: Fischer esterification: C6H5COOH + CH3OH (H2SO4) gives C6H5COOCH3 (methyl benzoate) + H2O. The carboxylic acid reacts with alcohol to form the ester.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Benzyl methyl ether involves benzyl alcohol and methanol. Phenyl acetate involves phenol and acetic acid. Benzoic anhydride is formed by dehydration of two benzoic acid molecules.

questions.question_text: How does Clemmensen reduction differ from Wolff-Kishner reduction in terms of reaction conditions?

options.text: Clemmensen uses acidic conditions (Zn-Hg/HCl) while Wolff-Kishner uses basic conditions (NH2NH2/KOH)
Clemmensen uses basic conditions while Wolff-Kishner uses acidic conditions
Both use acidic conditions but different catalysts
Clemmensen reduces only aldehydes while Wolff-Kishner reduces only ketones

questions.explanation_correct: Clemmensen reduction uses Zn-Hg amalgam with concentrated HCl (strongly acidic conditions), while Wolff-Kishner reduction uses hydrazine (NH2NH2) with KOH at high temperature (strongly basic conditions). Both reduce C=O to CH2 but under opposite pH conditions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The conditions are the reverse of option B. Both reactions can reduce both aldehydes and ketones to methylene groups; they are not selective for one class. The key distinction is acidic vs basic medium.

questions.question_text: How does the product of aldol condensation differ from the product of Cannizzaro reaction when two molecules of the same aldehyde react?

options.text: Aldol gives a beta-hydroxy carbonyl compound; Cannizzaro gives an alcohol and a carboxylate salt
Aldol gives an ester; Cannizzaro gives an alcohol
Aldol gives a carboxylic acid; Cannizzaro gives an alkane
Both reactions give the same products but by different mechanisms

questions.explanation_correct: Aldol condensation (requiring alpha-H) produces a beta-hydroxy aldehyde or ketone through C-C bond formation. Cannizzaro reaction (requiring no alpha-H) is a disproportionation giving one molecule of alcohol and one of carboxylate salt. The product types are fundamentally different.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An ester is formed in Tischenko reaction, not aldol condensation. Neither reaction gives an alkane or carboxylic acid as a direct product. The two reactions give entirely different products.

questions.question_text: How does the acidity of p-nitrobenzoic acid differ from that of p-methoxybenzoic acid?

options.text: p-Nitrobenzoic acid is more acidic because -NO2 is electron-withdrawing, stabilising the carboxylate ion
p-Methoxybenzoic acid is more acidic because -OCH3 increases polarity of the O-H bond
Both have equal acidity because the substituent is para to the carboxyl group
p-Nitrobenzoic acid is less acidic because -NO2 destabilises the carboxylate ion through steric strain

questions.explanation_correct: The -NO2 group is a strong electron-withdrawing group (-I and -R effects) that stabilises the carboxylate ion by dispersing the negative charge, increasing acidity. The -OCH3 group is electron-donating (+R > -I), destabilising the carboxylate ion and decreasing acidity. Hence p-nitrobenzoic acid is significantly more acidic.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The -OCH3 group actually decreases acidity through electron donation, not increases it. Para substituents do affect acidity through inductive and resonance effects. The -NO2 group stabilises, not destabilises, the conjugate base.

questions.question_text: How does Rosenmund reduction differ from Stephen reduction in the starting material used to prepare aldehydes?

options.text: Both use acid chlorides but with different catalysts
Rosenmund uses acid chlorides (RCOCl) while Stephen uses nitriles (RCN)
Rosenmund uses nitriles while Stephen uses acid chlorides
Rosenmund uses carboxylic acids while Stephen uses esters

questions.explanation_correct: Rosenmund reduction starts from acid chlorides (RCOCl) using H2/Pd-BaSO4 to give RCHO. Stephen reduction starts from nitriles (RCN) using SnCl2/HCl followed by hydrolysis to give RCHO. Both are routes to aldehydes but from different functional group precursors.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The starting materials are reversed in option C. Neither reaction uses carboxylic acids or esters as starting materials. Though both give aldehydes, they start from different functional groups.

questions.question_text: How does Tollens' test differ from Fehling's test in their ability to distinguish aromatic and aliphatic aldehydes?

options.text: Tollens' test is positive for both aromatic and aliphatic aldehydes; Fehling's test is positive only for aliphatic aldehydes
Fehling's test is positive for both; Tollens' test is positive only for aliphatic aldehydes
Both tests are positive for all aldehydes without distinction
Both tests are negative for aromatic aldehydes

questions.explanation_correct: Tollens' reagent (ammoniacal AgNO3) is a milder oxidant and gives a positive silver mirror test with both aliphatic and aromatic aldehydes. Fehling's solution (alkaline Cu2+ tartrate) gives a red Cu2O precipitate only with aliphatic aldehydes; aromatic aldehydes like benzaldehyde do not reduce Fehling's solution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fehling's test fails for aromatic aldehydes, so options B and C are incorrect. Tollens' test works for aromatic aldehydes too, so option D is incorrect.

questions.question_text: A carbonyl compound forms a cyanohydrin on reaction with HCN, gives a positive iodoform test with I2/NaOH, and does not give a silver mirror with Tollens' reagent. The compound is best classified as:
questions.explanation_correct: Cyanohydrin formation confirms a carbonyl group. A positive iodoform test indicates a CH3CO- group. A negative Tollens' test rules out aldehydes (both aliphatic and aromatic). The compound must therefore be a methyl ketone (e.g., acetone, acetophenone).
questions.explanation_incorrect: An aliphatic aldehyde would give a positive Tollens' test. An aromatic aldehyde would also give a positive Tollens' test. A carboxylic acid does not form cyanohydrins under standard conditions.

questions.question_text: An aldehyde does not undergo aldol condensation with dilute NaOH but undergoes disproportionation in concentrated NaOH to give an alcohol and a carboxylate salt. This aldehyde is best classified as:
questions.explanation_correct: Aldehydes without alpha-hydrogen (e.g., HCHO, C6H5CHO, (CH3)3CCHO) cannot undergo aldol condensation. Instead, they undergo Cannizzaro reaction (disproportionation) in concentrated NaOH, giving one molecule of alcohol and one of carboxylate salt.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Aldehydes with alpha-hydrogens undergo aldol condensation, not Cannizzaro. Ketones are not described here. Carboxylic acids do not undergo disproportionation in NaOH.

questions.question_text: A compound with molecular formula C2H4O2 is soluble in NaHCO3 with effervescence, forms dimers through hydrogen bonding, and reacts with PCl5 to give a product with formula C2H3OCl. This compound is best classified as:
questions.explanation_correct: Dissolving in NaHCO3 with effervescence (CO2 release) confirms the compound is a carboxylic acid. Dimer formation through H-bonding is characteristic of carboxylic acids. Reaction with PCl5 giving C2H3OCl (acetyl chloride, CH3COCl) confirms it is acetic acid (CH3COOH).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Methyl formate (HCOOCH3) is an ester and would not dissolve in NaHCO3 with effervescence. Glycolaldehyde (HOCH2CHO) is a hydroxy aldehyde, not acidic enough for NaHCO3. An anhydride has a different molecular formula.

questions.question_text: A compound gives a positive 2,4-DNP test (confirming a carbonyl group), does NOT give a positive Tollens' test, and on Clemmensen reduction yields ethylbenzene. This compound is best classified as:
questions.explanation_correct: A positive 2,4-DNP test confirms a carbonyl group. A negative Tollens' test rules out aldehydes, so it must be a ketone. Clemmensen reduction converting C=O to CH2 to give ethylbenzene (C6H5CH2CH3) means the starting material is C6H5COCH3 (acetophenone), a methyl aryl ketone.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Benzaldehyde would give a positive Tollens' test. Phenylacetic acid is a carboxylic acid that would not give a 2,4-DNP test. Styrene is an alkene with no carbonyl group.

questions.question_text: Riya is working on a synthesis project in her college organic chemistry lab. She needs to convert acetaldehyde to lactic acid (2-hydroxypropanoic acid) in two steps. She first reacts acetaldehyde with HCN in the presence of a base catalyst to obtain an intermediate, which she then plans to hydrolyse. What is the intermediate compound Riya obtains in the first step?
questions.explanation_correct: HCN adds to the carbonyl group of acetaldehyde (nucleophilic addition) to form acetaldehyde cyanohydrin, CH3CH(OH)CN (2-hydroxypropanenitrile). Hydrolysis of the -CN group gives -COOH, converting it to lactic acid (2-hydroxypropanoic acid, CH3CH(OH)COOH). Riya's intermediate is the cyanohydrin.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An oxime is formed with hydroxylamine, not HCN. 3-Hydroxybutanal is the aldol product. Ethanol would require reduction, not HCN addition.

questions.question_text: Amit is performing qualitative analysis in his school laboratory. He tests an unknown organic liquid with Tollens' reagent and observes a silver mirror. He then performs Fehling's test but observes no red precipitate. Finally, he adds 2,4-DNP reagent and gets an orange precipitate. Based on Amit's observations, which compound is the unknown liquid most likely to be?
questions.explanation_correct: A positive Tollens' test (silver mirror) confirms the compound is an aldehyde. A negative Fehling's test rules out aliphatic aldehydes (which reduce Fehling's solution). A positive 2,4-DNP test confirms the carbonyl group. The compound that satisfies all three observations is benzaldehyde, an aromatic aldehyde.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Acetaldehyde would give a positive Fehling's test as well. Acetone would not give a positive Tollens' test. Ethanol would not give a positive Tollens' test or 2,4-DNP test.

questions.question_text: Priya is studying the effect of substituents on acid strength for her NEET preparation. She has four aqueous solutions of equal concentration: (I) CH3COOH, (II) FCH2COOH, (III) ClCH2COOH, (IV) BrCH2COOH. She measures the pH of each solution. Which solution will Priya find has the lowest pH?
questions.explanation_correct: The lowest pH corresponds to the strongest acid (highest H+ concentration). Among haloacetic acids, the -I effect increases with electronegativity of the halogen: F > Cl > Br. Therefore FCH2COOH is the strongest acid and its solution will have the lowest pH. Order of acid strength: FCH2COOH > ClCH2COOH > BrCH2COOH > CH3COOH.
questions.explanation_incorrect: CH3COOH is the weakest acid here (no electron-withdrawing halogen). ClCH2COOH and BrCH2COOH are stronger than acetic acid but weaker than FCH2COOH because F has the highest electronegativity.

questions.question_text: Rohan is working in a pharmaceutical research lab where he needs to prepare an aldehyde from a nitrile. He treats benzonitrile (C6H5CN) with SnCl2/HCl, followed by hydrolysis with water. What product does Rohan obtain?
questions.explanation_correct: This is the Stephen reduction: RCN + SnCl2/HCl gives an aldimine salt, which on hydrolysis gives RCHO. Benzonitrile (C6H5CN) is converted to benzaldehyde (C6H5CHO) via the intermediate imine hydrochloride. Rohan obtains benzaldehyde.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Benzoic acid would require full oxidation of the nitrile. Benzylamine would be formed by reduction with LiAlH4. Benzyl alcohol would require reduction of benzaldehyde with NaBH4/LiAlH4.

questions.question_text: Meera is designing a synthesis route in which she needs to convert acetophenone (C6H5COCH3) to ethylbenzene (C6H5CH2CH3). Her professor advises her that the substrate is sensitive to basic conditions. Which reduction method should Meera choose?
questions.explanation_correct: Since the substrate is sensitive to basic conditions, Meera should avoid Wolff-Kishner reduction (which uses KOH/high temperature). Clemmensen reduction (Zn-Hg/conc. HCl) operates under acidic conditions and converts C=O to CH2, giving ethylbenzene from acetophenone.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Wolff-Kishner reduction uses strongly basic conditions (KOH), which are unsuitable here. NaBH4 reduces C=O to CHOH (gives 1-phenylethanol), not to CH2. Pd/BaSO4 is used in Rosenmund reduction of acid chlorides, not for complete deoxygenation.

questions.question_text: A student believes that all alkynes on acid-catalysed hydration give ketones. Which of the following is an exception to this generalisation?

options.text: Propyne gives acetone instead of a ketone
Acetylene (ethyne) gives acetaldehyde, an aldehyde, not a ketone
But-2-yne gives butanone instead of a ketone
Phenylacetylene gives acetophenone instead of a ketone

questions.explanation_correct: Acetylene (HC triple bond CH) is the exception. On acid-catalysed hydration, it forms vinyl alcohol (enol) which tautomerises to acetaldehyde (CH3CHO), an aldehyde, not a ketone. All other alkynes follow Markovnikov addition to give ketones.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Acetone is a ketone, so propyne follows the general rule. Butanone and acetophenone are both ketones. The only exception is acetylene (the simplest alkyne), which gives an aldehyde because both carbons of the triple bond bear a hydrogen.

questions.question_text: Benzoic acid does NOT undergo the Hell-Volhard-Zelinsky (HVZ) reaction. What makes benzoic acid an exception?

options.text: Benzoic acid has no alpha-hydrogen atoms on a saturated carbon adjacent to the carboxyl group
Benzoic acid is too weak an acid to undergo halogenation
The benzene ring deactivates the carboxyl group completely
Bromine cannot react with aromatic compounds under HVZ conditions

questions.explanation_correct: The HVZ reaction requires alpha-hydrogen atoms on a saturated carbon adjacent to the -COOH group. In benzoic acid (C6H5COOH), the carbon alpha to the carboxyl is part of the aromatic ring and has no replaceable alpha-hydrogens on a sp3 carbon. Therefore, HVZ reaction does not occur.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Acid strength is not the issue; the mechanism requires alpha-C-H bonds. The benzene ring does not deactivate the carboxyl group for HVZ; the issue is structural (no alpha-H). Bromine can react with aromatics but through electrophilic substitution, not HVZ.

questions.question_text: A student assumes that all aldehydes give a positive Fehling's test. Which of the following is a well-known exception?
questions.explanation_correct: Benzaldehyde and other aromatic aldehydes do not reduce Fehling's solution, making them exceptions to the general rule that aldehydes give a positive Fehling's test. This is because Fehling's solution (alkaline medium) causes a Cannizzaro-like reaction with benzaldehyde instead of reduction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Formaldehyde, acetaldehyde, and propanal are all aliphatic aldehydes that readily reduce Fehling's solution to give the characteristic red Cu2O precipitate.

questions.question_text: Why is PCC (pyridinium chlorochromate) preferred over KMnO4 for oxidising a primary alcohol to an aldehyde?

options.text: PCC is a stronger oxidising agent that reacts faster
PCC is a mild and selective oxidant that stops at the aldehyde stage without over-oxidation to the carboxylic acid
PCC works only in aqueous medium which stabilises the aldehyde
KMnO4 cannot oxidise primary alcohols at all

questions.explanation_correct: PCC is a mild, selective oxidant that operates in anhydrous conditions (typically in CH2Cl2). It oxidises primary alcohols to aldehydes and stops there, preventing further oxidation to carboxylic acids. KMnO4 is a strong oxidant that over-oxidises the aldehyde to a carboxylic acid.
questions.explanation_incorrect: PCC is a milder (not stronger) oxidant. PCC is used in anhydrous non-aqueous solvents, not aqueous medium. KMnO4 can oxidise primary alcohols but goes all the way to carboxylic acids.

questions.question_text: Why does benzophenone (C6H5COC6H5) not form a bisulphite addition product with NaHSO3, whereas acetone (CH3COCH3) does?

options.text: Because benzophenone is less polar than acetone
Because the two bulky phenyl groups in benzophenone cause too much steric hindrance for nucleophilic attack at the carbonyl carbon
Because NaHSO3 reacts only with aldehydes, not with any ketones
Because benzophenone does not have a carbonyl group

questions.explanation_correct: Bisulphite addition requires the nucleophile (HSO3-) to attack the carbonyl carbon. In benzophenone, two large phenyl groups create severe steric hindrance around the carbonyl carbon, preventing approach of the bulky bisulphite ion. Additionally, phenyl groups reduce electrophilicity through resonance. Acetone has smaller methyl groups allowing the reaction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Polarity alone is not the determining factor. NaHSO3 does react with methyl ketones and some other ketones, not only aldehydes. Benzophenone certainly has a C=O group; the issue is accessibility.

questions.question_text: Why does acetic acid (pKa ~ 4.76) behave as a stronger acid than ethanol (pKa ~ 16) despite both having an O-H bond?

options.text: Because acetic acid has a higher molecular mass than ethanol
Because the acetate ion is stabilised by resonance delocalisation of the negative charge over two equivalent oxygen atoms, greatly lowering the energy of the conjugate base
Because the O-H bond in acetic acid is weaker due to the longer bond length
Because ethanol forms stronger hydrogen bonds preventing ionisation

questions.explanation_correct: When acetic acid ionises, the resulting acetate ion (CH3COO-) is stabilised by delocalisation of the negative charge equally over two oxygen atoms through two equivalent resonance structures. The ethoxide ion (CH3CH2O-) from ethanol has no such resonance stabilisation. Greater conjugate base stability drives the equilibrium towards ionisation, making acetic acid much more acidic.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Molecular mass does not determine acid strength. The O-H bond length is not significantly different. While hydrogen bonding exists in ethanol, it is not the primary reason for the 11 pKa unit difference; resonance stabilisation of the conjugate base is the dominant factor.
